'''Damien George Rice''' (born 7 December 1973) is an Irish singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ross |first1=Alex |date=29 October 2021 |title=Ed Sheeran confirms his next album is ready to drop 🙌 |url=https://planetradio.co.uk/kiss/entertainment/music/ed-sheeran-next-album-complete/ |website=KISS |access-date=10 November 2021 |quote="fellow singer-songwriter Damien Rice had been a huge inspiration" |language=en}}</ref> He began his career as a member of the 1990s rock group [[Juniper (band)|Juniper]], who were signed to [[Polygram Records]] in 1997. The band enjoyed moderate success in Ireland with two released singles, "The World is Dead" and "Weatherman".<ref>{{Cite web|title=Damien Rice|url=https://open.spotify.com/artist/14r9dR01KeBLFfylVSKCZQ|access-date=24 February 2021|website=Spotify|language=en}}</ref> After leaving the band in 1998, Rice worked as a farmer in [[Tuscany]] and busked throughout Europe before returning to Ireland in 2001 and beginning a solo career. The rest of Juniper went on to perform under the name [[Bell X1 (band)|Bell X1]].

In 2002, Rice released his debut album, ''[[O (Damien Rice album)|O]]''. It reached No. 8 on the [[UK Albums Chart]], won the [[Shortlist Music Prize]], and generated three top 30 singles in the UK. He released his second album, ''[[9 (Damien Rice album)|9]]'', in 2006. After eight years of various collaborations, Rice released his third studio album, ''[[My Favourite Faded Fantasy]]'', in 2014.<ref>{{cite web | publisher = iTunes Store | url = https://itunes.apple.com/album/my-favourite-faded-fantasy/id915106298?ign-mpt=uo%3D4 | title = iTunes Store (pre-order) | access-date = 8 September 2014 }}</ref> He has contributed music to charitable projects such as [[Songs for Tibet: The Art of Peace|Songs for Tibet]], the [[Enough Project]], and the Freedom Campaign.

==Early life==
Rice was born in [[Dublin]] on 7 December 1973, the son of George and Maureen Rice. He grew up in [[Celbridge]], [[Co. Kildare]] where he attended Salesian College.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=DamienRice.com |url=http://www.damienrice.com/faq.html |title=FAQ – Where was Damien born and where did he grow up? |date=n.d. |access-date=24 April 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070502083031/http://www.damienrice.com/faq.html |archive-date=2 May 2007 }}</ref> He is the second cousin of Irish singer [[Stevie Mann]] and English composer [[David Arnold]].<ref name="ALLMUSIC" />

==Career==
===Juniper===
Rice formed the rock band [[Juniper (band)|Juniper]] along with [[Paul Noonan]], Dominic Philips, [[David Geraghty]] and [[Brian Crosby (composer)|Brian Crosby]] in 1991. The band met whilst they were schoolmates in Celbridge. After touring throughout Ireland, they released their debut [[Extended Play|EP]] ''Manna'' in 1995.<ref name="HOTPRESS">{{cite magazine|url = http://www.hotpress.com/archive/416531.html|title = Should We Talk About The Weather?|magazine = [[Hot Press]]|access-date =12 September 2009}} (Fee for article)</ref> Based in [[Straffan]], the band continued touring and signed a six album record deal with [[PolyGram]]. Their recording projects generated the singles "Weatherman" and "The World is Dead", which received favourable reviews.<ref name="HOTPRESS" /> They also recorded a song named "Tongue", which was never released.

After achieving some of his musical goals with Juniper, Rice became frustrated with the artistic compromises required by the record label, and he left the band in 1998.<ref name="YAHOO">{{cite web|url=http://music.yahoo.com/library/default.asp?m=content&add=interview&i=12063810& |title=The story of ''O'' |publisher=[[Yahoo]] |access-date=12 September 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070220112647/http://music.yahoo.com/library/default.asp?m=content&add=interview&i=12063810& |archive-date=20 February 2007 }}</ref> He moved to Italy, where he settled in [[Tuscany]] and took up farming for a time, then returned to Ireland before busking around Europe.<ref name="YAHOO" /> He returned to Italy a second time and gave a demo recording to his second cousin, English composer [[David Arnold]], who then provided him with a mobile recording studio.<ref name="ALLMUSIC" />

===Solo career===
[[File:Damien Rice @ Coachella 07.jpg|thumb|Rice performing at the 2007 [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival|Coachella Festival]]]]
In 2001, Rice's song "The Blower's Daughter" made a top-40 chart.<ref name = "ALLMUSIC">{{cite web|url = {{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p557508|pure_url=yes}}|title = Damien Rice – Biography|publisher = [[AllMusic]]|access-date =13 September 2009}}</ref> Over the next year he continued to record his album with guitarist Mark Kelly, New York drummer [[Tom Osander]] aka Tomo, Paris pianist Jean Meunier, London producer David Arnold, County Meath vocalist [[Lisa Hannigan]] and cellist [[Vyvienne Long]]. Rice then embarked on a tour of Ireland with Hannigan, Tomo, Vyvienne, Mark and Dublin bassist Shane Fitzsimons.

In 2002, Rice's debut album ''[[O (Damien Rice album)|O]]'' was released in Ireland, the UK and the United States.<ref name = "Chartstats O">{{cite web|url = https://www.officialcharts.com/archive/official-albums-chart/|title = Official Charts Company for ''O''|publisher = [[Official Charts Company]]|access-date =12 September 2009}}</ref> The album peaked at No. 8 on the [[UK Albums Chart]] and remained on the chart for 97 weeks, selling 650,000 copies in the US.<ref name = "Chartstats O"/><ref name = "Billboard"/> The album won the [[Shortlist Music Prize]] and the songs "Cannonball" and "Volcano" became top 30 hits in the UK.<ref name = "Billboard">{{cite magazine|url = http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/57098/damien-rice-readies-sophomore-album|title = Damien Rice Readies second album|magazine = [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date =12 September 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishcharts.ie/search/placement |title=Damien Rice singles placement |publisher=irishcharts.ie |access-date=12 September 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721125210/http://irishcharts.ie/search/placement |archive-date=21 July 2011 }}</ref>

In 2005, Rice participated in the Freedom Campaign, the [[Burma Campaign UK]], and the [[U.S. Campaign for Burma]] to free Burmese democracy movement leader [[Aung San Suu Kyi]].<ref>{{cite web|date=n.d.|title=Aung San Suu Kyi the world's only imprisoned Nobel Peace Prize recipient|url=http://www.actionburma.com/|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313065931/http://www.burmacampaign.org.uk/|archive-date=13 March 2012|access-date=24 April 2007|publisher=The Burma Campaign UK|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He campaigned for her release by writing the song "[[Unplayed Piano]]", which he performed at the 2006 Nobel Peace Prize Concert in [[Oslo]].<ref>{{Cite web|date=2005-05-10|title=Damien Rice releases new single in support of Aung San Suu Kyi|url=https://burmacampaign.org.uk/damien-rice-releases-new-single-in-support-of-aung-san-suu-kyi/|access-date=2021-12-23|website=Burma Campaign UK|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Newsdesk|first=The Hot Press|title=Damien Rice participates in Nobel Peace Prize ceremony|url=https://www.hotpress.com/music/damien-rice-participates-in-nobel-peace-prize-ceremony-2842993|access-date=2021-12-23|website=Hotpress}}</ref>

In 2006, Rice released his second album, ''[[9 (Damien Rice album)|9]]'', which was recorded during the two previous years.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=DamienRice.com |url=http://www.damienrice.com/music.php?ref=110 |title=9 – Release info |date=n.d. |access-date=24 April 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070518043107/http://www.damienrice.com/music.php?ref=110 |archive-date=18 May 2007 }}</ref> 2007 was a year of touring with Rice appearing at England's [[Glastonbury Festival]] and the [[Rock Werchter]] festival in Belgium.{{citation needed|date=May 2021}} In 2008 he contributed the song "Making Noise" for the album ''[[Songs for Tibet: The Art of Peace]]'' in support of the [[14th Dalai Lama]] and [[Tibet]].<ref>E-Online (22 July 2008) [http://uk.eonline.com/uberblog/b147502_sting_matthews_mayer_gamer_tibet_beijing.html Sting, Matthews, Mayer Gamer for Tibet Than Beijing] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724212652/http://uk.eonline.com/uberblog/b147502_sting_matthews_mayer_gamer_tibet_beijing.html |date=24 July 2008 }}</ref>

In 2010, Rice contributed the song "Lonely Soldier" to the [[Enough Project]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://raisehopeforcongomusic.org/ |title=Raise Hope for Congo |publisher=Raisehopeforcongomusic.org |access-date=8 October 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130622043628/http://raisehopeforcongomusic.org/ |archive-date=22 June 2013 |url-status=dead }}</ref> and played at the Iceland Inspires concert held in Hljómskálagarðurinn near [[Reykjavík]] centrum.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inspiredbyiceland.com |title=Inspired By Iceland |publisher=Inspired By Iceland |access-date=8 October 2011}}</ref> Records released in the UK, Europe and other countries were published by [[14th Floor Records]] via [[Warner Music Group|Warner Music]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.damienrice.com/faq.html |title=FAQ at |publisher=Damienrice.com |access-date=8 October 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930141326/http://www.damienrice.com/faq.html |archive-date=30 September 2011 }}</ref> In spring 2011, Rice featured on the debut album by French actress and singer [[Melanie Laurent]]. He appears on two tracks on her debut album ''[[En t'attendant]]'' while collaborating on a total of five tracks which feature on the album.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.damienrice.com/news/ |title=Music |publisher=Damien Rice |access-date=8 October 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930141608/http://www.damienrice.com/news/ |archive-date=30 September 2011 }}</ref> In May 2013, Rice told the audience at the South Korea [[Seoul Jazz Festival]] 2013 that he was working on a new album.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V-rYpnDzTKI |title=New Album Confirmation |via=YouTube |access-date=19 May 2013}}</ref>

On 4 September 2014, Rice's official Twitter account announced his third album, ''[[My Favourite Faded Fantasy]]'', to be released on 31 October. On his official website the date given for the official release was 3 November 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://damienrice.warnerartists.net/eu |title=Album information |publisher=Damienrice.com/ |access-date=14 January 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141102032531/http://damienrice.warnerartists.net/eu |archive-date=2 November 2014 |url-status=dead  }}</ref> The album, featuring the first single "I Don't Want To Change You", was released worldwide on 10 November 2014 to critical acclaim from NPR's Robin Hilton and the London ''[[Evening Standard]]''.{{Citation needed|date=February 2019}}

In 2020, Rice covered [[Sia]]'s "[[Chandelier (song)|Chandelier]]", with his cover appearing on the ''[[Songs for Australia]]'' benefit album.
